expanded_description: Graphs are everywhere—in newspapers, business reports, scientific journals, and social media. They tell stories about real-world phenomena: how temperatures change, how profits fluctuate, how populations grow, how distances vary with time. Learning to interpret these graphs in context is an essential life skill that connects mathematical understanding to practical applications.

core_concept.principle: Real-world graphs have context: the axes represent specific quantities with units, and the graph itself tells a story. Analyzing real-world graphs means connecting mathematical features (intercepts, slope, maxima/minima, increasing/decreasing) to real-world meanings (starting point, rate of change, peak values, trends). The shape of the graph reveals the story.
core_concept.explanation: Think of a real-world graph as a photograph of a process. The x-axis is like time or some other input; the y-axis is what you're measuring. The line or curve shows how the measurement changed. A steep slope means rapid change; a flat line means no change. A peak is the high point of the story; a valley is the low point. Your job is to read the photograph and describe what happened.

sections.introduction: Distance-time graphs are among the most common real-world graphs. They tell the story of motion—how far something has traveled over time.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 3.9.2: A distance-time graph shows motion over time.

key_concept.definition: In a distance-time graph, time is on the x-axis (usually in seconds, minutes, or hours) and distance is on the y-axis (in meters, miles, etc.). The slope represents speed: steeper slope = faster speed. A horizontal line means the object is stopped. A decreasing line means the object is returning toward the start.
key_concept.context: These graphs model trips, races, commutes, and any situation where position changes over time. Understanding them helps interpret journeys and predict arrival times.

image.alt: Distance-time graph with slope = speed, flat = stopped, decreasing = returning
image.caption: Figure 3.9.3: Anatomy of a distance-time graph.

examples.process: Car traveling at 60 mph for 2 hours
examples.explanation: Graph is straight line from (0,0) to (2,120)
Distance stays constant while time increases

classifications.behavior: Object is going back the way it came.

image.alt: Line with negative slope on distance-time graph
image.caption: Figure 3.9.6: Returning - negative slope.

characteristics: Graph curves upward (getting steeper) or downward (getting less steep)
classifications.behavior: Object speeding up or slowing down.

image.alt: Curved line getting steeper on distance-time graph
image.caption: Figure 3.9.7: Accelerating - curved line.

examples.explanation: Graph curves upward as speed increases

worked_examples.title: Interpreting a Road Trip Graph

image.alt: Distance-time graph for a road trip with labeled segments
image.caption: Figure 3.9.8: A family road trip.

worked_examples.problem: The graph in Figure 3.9.8 shows a family's road trip. Describe what is happening during each segment: A-B, B-C, C-D, D-E, and E-F.

step_by_step.explanation: Straight line with positive slope from (0,0) to (1,60)
step_by_step.calculation: Traveling at 60 mph for 1 hour, covering 60 miles

image.caption: Figure 3.9.9: Segment A-B - traveling at constant speed.

step_by_step.calculation: Stopped for 1 hour (rest stop or traffic jam)

step_by_step.explanation: Straight line steeper than A-B from (2,60) to (3,120)
step_by_step.calculation: Traveling at 60 mph again, covering another 60 miles

image.caption: Figure 3.9.11: Segment C-D - traveling at same speed.

step_by_step.explanation: Straight line less steep from (3,120) to (5,160)
step_by_step.calculation: Traveling slower: 40 mph for 2 hours, covering 40 miles total (20 mph average?) Wait: 160-120=40 miles over 2 hours = 20 mph

image.caption: Figure 3.9.12: Segment D-E - slower speed (20 mph).

step_by_step.explanation: Line with negative slope from (5,160) to (7,0)
step_by_step.calculation: Returning home: traveled 160 miles back in 2 hours = 80 mph

worked_examples.final_answer:
A-B: Traveling 60 mph for 1 hour
B-C: Stopped for 1 hour
C-D: Traveling 60 mph for 1 hour
D-E: Traveling 20 mph for 2 hours
E-F: Returning home at 80 mph for 2 hours
worked_examples.concept_applied: Slope = speed, horizontal = stopped, negative slope = returning.

worked_examples.title: Comparing Speeds

image.alt: Two distance-time graphs on same axes
image.caption: Figure 3.9.14: Compare the speeds of two cars.

worked_examples.problem: The graph shows the distance traveled by two cars over time. Which car is faster? How can you tell?

step_by_step.explanation: Car A's line is steeper than Car B's line at the same time
step_by_step.calculation: Steeper slope means greater speed, so Car A is faster

image.alt: Steeper slope highlighted for Car A
image.caption: Figure 3.9.15: Car A has steeper slope = faster.

step_by_step.explanation: At t=2 hours, Car A has gone 120 miles, Car B has gone 80 miles
step_by_step.calculation: Car A speed = 60 mph, Car B speed = 40 mph

worked_examples.final_answer: Car A is faster (steeper slope = higher speed).
worked_examples.concept_applied: On the same time scale, steeper slope = faster speed.

sections.introduction: Speed-time graphs show how speed changes over time, revealing acceleration and deceleration.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 3.9.17: A speed-time graph shows how speed changes.

key_concept.definition: In a speed-time graph, time is on the x-axis and speed is on the y-axis. The slope represents acceleration (rate of change of speed). A horizontal line means constant speed (zero acceleration). A line with positive slope means speeding up; negative slope means slowing down. The area under the graph represents distance traveled.
key_concept.context: These graphs are used in physics, engineering, and analyzing vehicle performance. They provide more detailed information about motion than distance-time graphs.

image.alt: Speed-time graph with slope = acceleration, area = distance
image.caption: Figure 3.9.18: Anatomy of a speed-time graph.

worked_examples.title: Interpreting a Speed-Time Graph

image.alt: Speed-time graph for a car trip
image.caption: Figure 3.9.19: A car's speed over time.

worked_examples.problem: The graph in Figure 3.9.19 shows a car's speed over a 10-second interval. Describe what is happening during each segment: 0-4 seconds, 4-6 seconds, 6-10 seconds.

step_by_step.explanation: Line with positive slope from (0,0) to (4,20)
step_by_step.calculation: Car is accelerating: speed increases from 0 to 20 m/s in 4 seconds. Acceleration = $20/4 = 5$ m/s²
Car maintains constant speed of 20 m/s for 2 seconds. Acceleration = 0.

step_by_step.explanation: Line with negative slope from (6,20) to (10,0)
step_by_step.calculation: Car decelerates: speed decreases from 20 to 0 m/s in 4 seconds. Deceleration = $-20/4 = -5$ m/s²

worked_examples.final_answer:
0-4s: Accelerating to 20 m/s
4-6s: Constant speed 20 m/s
6-10s: Decelerating to stop
worked_examples.concept_applied: Slope = acceleration, horizontal = constant speed, negative slope = deceleration.

worked_examples.title: Finding Distance from Speed-Time Graph

image.alt: Speed-time graph with area under curve shaded
image.caption: Figure 3.9.23: Area under speed-time graph = distance.

worked_examples.problem: For the graph in Figure 3.9.23, find the total distance traveled.

step_by_step.explanation: The area under the speed-time graph is distance. Break into shapes: triangle (0-4s), rectangle (4-6s), triangle (6-10s)

image.caption: Figure 3.9.24: Area broken into geometric shapes.

step_by_step.calculation: $\frac{1}{2} \times 4 \times 20 = 40$ meters
$2 \times 20 = 40$ meters

worked_examples.concept_applied: Area under speed-time graph = distance traveled.

sections.introduction: Temperature-time graphs show how temperature changes over time, revealing heating, cooling, and phase changes.

key_concept.definition: In a temperature-time graph, time is on the x-axis (hours, days, months) and temperature on the y-axis (usually °C or °F). The slope represents rate of temperature change. Flat sections indicate constant temperature (possible phase change). Peaks and valleys show maximum and minimum temperatures.
key_concept.context: These graphs appear in weather reports, climate studies, cooking, and industrial processes. They help us understand daily and seasonal patterns.

image.alt: Temperature graph with labeled features: increasing, decreasing, max, min
image.caption: Figure 3.9.27: Anatomy of a temperature graph.

worked_examples.title: Interpreting Daily Temperature

image.caption: Figure 3.9.28: Temperature on a summer day.

worked_examples.problem:
The graph in Figure 3.9.28 shows temperature over a 24-hour period. Answer:
a) What was the temperature at midnight?
b) When was the temperature highest? Lowest?
c) During what hours was temperature increasing?
d) What was the temperature range?

step_by_step.calculation: At midnight, temperature ≈ $15°C$

Highest at t=14 (2 PM): $28°C$
Lowest at t=4 (4 AM): $12°C$

image.caption: Figure 3.9.30: Max at 2 PM, min at 4 AM.

step_by_step.explanation: Where graph goes up as time increases
step_by_step.calculation: Increasing from 4 AM to 2 PM (hours 4-14)

image.caption: Figure 3.9.31: Increasing from 4 AM to 2 PM.

worked_examples.final_answer:
a) $15°C$
b) Highest: 2 PM ($28°C$), Lowest: 4 AM ($12°C$)
c) 4 AM to 2 PM
d) $16°C$ range
worked_examples.concept_applied: Temperature graphs show daily patterns: coolest near dawn, warmest mid-afternoon.

worked_examples.title: Heating and Cooling

image.caption: Figure 3.9.32: Heating water from room temperature to boiling.

worked_examples.problem: The graph shows water being heated from room temperature to boiling, then cooling. Describe what is happening during each phase.

step_by_step.calculation: Water heating up at constant rate
Water boiling - temperature constant while phase change occurs

step_by_step.explanation: Temperature decreasing from 100°C to room temperature
step_by_step.calculation: Water cooling down

worked_examples.final_answer:
A-B: Heating to boiling point
B-C: Boiling (phase change, constant temp)
C-D: Cooling back to room temperature
worked_examples.concept_applied: Flat sections in temperature graphs often indicate phase changes (melting, boiling, freezing).

sections.introduction: Business graphs show relationships involving money: costs, revenues, profits, and market trends.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 3.9.37: Business graphs show financial relationships.

key_concept.definition: In business graphs, the x-axis often represents quantity (items produced/sold) and the y-axis represents money (dollars). Cost functions typically start above zero (fixed costs) and increase. Revenue functions start at zero (no sales, no revenue). Profit = Revenue - Cost, so break-even occurs where they intersect.
key_concept.context: These graphs help businesses make decisions: How many items to produce? What price to charge? When will we break even? What's the maximum profit?

image.alt: Cost and revenue graphs with break-even point labeled
image.caption: Figure 3.9.38: Anatomy of cost/revenue graphs.

classifications.value: Total cost to produce x items.
classifications.behavior: Increases as more items are produced.

examples.process: Fixed cost $\$500$, variable cost $\$10$ per item

classifications.value: Total revenue from selling x items.
characteristics: Linear: $R(x) = px$ where p = price per item
classifications.behavior: Increases as more items are sold.

characteristics: Maximum profit at vertex if quadratic
classifications.behavior: May be negative at low quantities, positive at medium, negative again if diminishing returns.

image.alt: Profit function showing negative, break-even, positive regions
image.caption: Figure 3.9.41: Profit function.

worked_examples.title: Break-Even Analysis
worked_examples.problem:
The graph shows cost and revenue for a small business. Use the graph to find:
a) Fixed costs
b) Price per item
c) Variable cost per item
d) Break-even quantity
e) Profit at 100 items

step_by_step.explanation: Fixed costs = y-intercept of cost function
step_by_step.calculation: Cost line crosses y-axis at $(0, 200)$, so fixed costs = $\$200$
Revenue line goes through $(0,0)$ and $(100,1000)$, slope = $1000/100 = 10$, so price = $\$10$ per item

step_by_step.explanation: Variable cost = slope of cost function
step_by_step.calculation: Cost line goes through $(0,200)$ and $(100,700)$, slope = $(700-200)/100 = 500/100 = 5$, so variable cost = $\$5$ per item
Lines intersect at $x = 40$ items
Revenue at 100 = $1000$, Cost at 100 = $700$, Profit = $300$

image.alt: Gap between revenue and cost at x=100
image.caption: Figure 3.9.47: Profit at 100 items = $300.

worked_examples.final_answer:
a) $\$200$ fixed costs
b) $\$10$ per item
c) $\$5$ per item
d) 40 items
e) $\$300$ profit
worked_examples.concept_applied: Business graphs: intercepts give fixed costs, slopes give per-unit amounts, intersections give break-even.

sections.introduction: Growth and decay graphs show how quantities increase or decrease over time—population, investments, radioactive decay, etc.

key_concept.definition: Growth graphs curve upward (steepening over time), while decay graphs curve downward (flattening over time). Linear growth is a straight line; exponential growth is a J-shaped curve; exponential decay is a reverse-J curve.
key_concept.context: These graphs model population growth, compound interest, bacterial growth, radioactive decay, drug concentration in the body, and many natural phenomena.

image.alt: Comparison of linear, exponential growth, exponential decay
image.caption: Figure 3.9.50: Different growth patterns.

classifications.value: Growth rate proportional to current amount.
characteristics: Multiplies by same factor each time

examples.explanation: Curves upward as growth builds on itself

classifications.value: Decay rate proportional to current amount.
characteristics: Multiplies by same factor each time (factor < 1)
classifications.behavior: Fast at first, then levels off.

examples.explanation: Decreases quickly at first, then more slowly

worked_examples.title: Identifying Growth Types
worked_examples.problem: Identify each graph as linear growth, exponential growth, or exponential decay.

step_by_step.calculation: Linear growth
Exponential growth
Exponential decay

worked_examples.final_answer: A: Linear growth, B: Exponential growth, C: Exponential decay
worked_examples.concept_applied: Shape tells the story: straight = linear, J-curve = exponential growth, reverse-J = exponential decay.

sections.introduction: Sometimes multiple graphs on the same axes tell a richer story—comparing two quantities or showing relationships.

introduction_image.alt: Two graphs on same axes: supply and demand
introduction_image.caption: Figure 3.9.60: Multiple graphs together.

key_concept.definition: When multiple graphs appear on the same axes, their intersections, relative positions, and gaps between them convey information. Intersection points often represent equilibrium or equality. The vertical distance between graphs represents difference (profit = revenue - cost, surplus, etc.).
key_concept.context: Economics uses supply and demand graphs. Business uses cost and revenue. Science might compare experimental data to theoretical curves. Understanding multiple graphs is essential for comparative analysis.

image.alt: Supply and demand with equilibrium labeled
image.caption: Figure 3.9.61: Supply and demand graphs.

worked_examples.title: Supply and Demand

image.alt: Supply and demand curves with equilibrium
image.caption: Figure 3.9.62: Find equilibrium price and quantity.

worked_examples.problem:
The graph shows supply and demand for a product. Find:
a) Equilibrium price and quantity
b) Surplus or shortage at price $\$8$
c) Surplus or shortage at price $\$4$

step_by_step.explanation: Where supply and demand curves intersect
step_by_step.calculation: Intersection at $(50, 6)$, so equilibrium quantity = 50 units, price = $\$6$
Supply > Demand, so surplus of 40 units
Demand > Supply, so shortage of 40 units

worked_examples.final_answer:
a) 50 units at $\$6$
b) Surplus of 40 units at $\$8$
c) Shortage of 40 units at $\$4$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Intersection = equilibrium; above equilibrium = surplus; below = shortage.

In cost graphs, confusing fixed and variable costs

worked_examples.title: Correcting Real-World Graph Errors

image.caption: Figure 3.9.75: Find and correct the errors.

worked_examples.problem: A student analyzed a distance-time graph and wrote: 'The graph shows a car trip. The y-intercept is 0, meaning the car started at time 0. The slope is 60, so the car traveled 60 miles. There's a flat part where the slope is 0, meaning the car disappeared.' Identify and correct the errors.

step_by_step.explanation: Student correctly identified y-intercept as 0, but meaning is wrong
step_by_step.calculation: Correct: Y-intercept 0 means car started at distance 0 miles from starting point

step_by_step.explanation: Slope 60 means speed of 60 mph, not distance traveled
step_by_step.calculation: Correct: Car traveled at 60 miles per hour
Correct: Car was stopped (rest stop, traffic, etc.)

worked_examples.final_answer: Correct: Car started at distance 0, traveled at 60 mph, then stopped (not disappeared).

sections.introduction: Apply your real-world graph interpretation skills to a variety of contexts.

worked_examples.title: Mixed Practice Set
worked_examples.problem:
1) A distance-time graph shows: 0-2 hrs: slope 50, 2-3 hrs: horizontal at 100 miles, 3-5 hrs: slope -40. Describe the trip.
2) A temperature graph shows minimum at 6 AM ($10°C$) and maximum at 3 PM ($25°C$). When is temperature increasing?
3) Cost: $C(x)=8x+200$, Revenue: $R(x)=15x$. Find break-even quantity.
4) An investment grows exponentially from $\$1000$ to $\$2000$ in 5 years. Estimate doubling time.
5) Supply and demand intersect at (80, $12$). At $P=10$, demand=100, supply=60. Is there surplus or shortage?

step_by_step.explanation:
0-2 hrs: traveling at 50 mph (100 miles covered)
2-3 hrs: stopped for 1 hour at 100 miles
3-5 hrs: returning at 40 mph (80 miles back, ending at 20 miles)
step_by_step.calculation: Trip: 100 miles out, rest, then 80 miles back
Increasing from 6 AM to 3 PM
$7x = 200$ → $x ≈ 28.6$ items (break-even at 29 items)
Doubling time ≈ 5 years
Shortage of 40 units

worked_examples.final_answer:
1) 100 miles out, rest 1 hr, return to 20 miles
2) 6 AM to 3 PM
3) 29 items
4) 5 years
5) Shortage of 40 units
worked_examples.concept_applied: Real-world graphs require connecting mathematical features to contextual meanings.

summary: Real-world graphs tell stories about practical situations. In distance-time graphs, slope represents speed, horizontal lines indicate stops, and negative slope means returning. In speed-time graphs, slope represents acceleration, and area under the curve gives distance traveled. Temperature-time graphs show daily or seasonal patterns, with peaks and valleys indicating extremes. Business graphs show cost (with y-intercept as fixed costs), revenue (through origin), and profit. Break-even occurs where cost equals revenue. Supply and demand graphs intersect at equilibrium price and quantity; above equilibrium creates surplus, below creates shortage. Growth graphs can be linear (constant rate), exponential growth (J-curve), or exponential decay (reverse-J). When interpreting real-world graphs, always consider units and context—connect mathematical features (intercepts, slopes, maxima) to real-world meanings (starting point, speed, peak temperature). Understanding these interpretations enables informed decision-making in business, science, and everyday life.
